causes: Italy's ambition to create a new empire in Africa under Mussolini's regime
Failure of the First Italo-Ethiopian War (1895–1896), which left Italy with unresolved territorial ambitions
Ethiopia's defiance of colonial encroachment and its status as one of the only independent African nations
Desire of Mussolini to boost national prestige and distract from internal economic problems
events_leading_up_to_war: Italy seeks to expand its East African colonies by targeting Ethiopia, a country not yet colonized
Mussolini leverages a border incident at Wal Wal to declare war
League of Nations condemns Italy's actions but fails to intervene decisively

result.territorial_changes: Ethiopia annexed into the Italian East Africa empire, uniting Eritrea, Somaliland, and Ethiopia under Italian rule

allies: Volunteer forces from other African nations, including some from Egypt and Sudan

major_battles.name: Battle of Adwa
major_battles.description: The climactic battle where Italian forces, after an initial setback, decisively defeated the Ethiopian defenses in the northern part of the country.

major_battles.name: Battle of Amba Aradam
major_battles.description: An early victory for Italian forces, where they surrounded and crushed Ethiopian resistance in the mountains, forcing a retreat.

major_battles.name: Battle of Mai Ceu
major_battles.description: A key clash where Italian forces, using superior technology, overwhelmed Ethiopian forces despite the latter's tenacious defense.

terms: Ethiopia is officially annexed by Italy, forming Italian East Africa
Haile Selassie I is exiled, with Italy declaring itself the ruler of Ethiopia
The League of Nations condemns Italy's actions, but sanctions prove ineffective
impact: Ethiopia remains under Italian control until 1941, when it is liberated by Allied forces during World War II
Mussolini consolidates power, showcasing Italy’s fascist military might
Ethiopia's exile government, led by Haile Selassie, gains international support, particularly in the fight against fascism

long_term_effects: Italy's military and economic strain, leading to significant problems during World War II
Strengthening of pan-African sentiments and international condemnation of European imperialism
Ethiopian resistance to colonial rule continues in the form of guerrilla warfare and diplomacy

economic: Italy gains control over key East African resources, including minerals, farmland, and trade routes
The war further entrenched Italian colonial control over the region, despite local resistance
political: Mussolini’s regime becomes more aggressive in its foreign policies, eventually leading to Italy’s involvement in World War II
The League of Nations' failure to stop Italy damages its credibility as a peacekeeping body
social: The war sees widespread use of chemical weapons, including mustard gas, leading to horrific casualties among Ethiopian civilians and soldiers
The defeat of Ethiopia leads to greater African unity movements, including later efforts for independence in the mid-20th century
